entry.answer: The text describes King Nahuṣa as becoming overly proud after gaining divine powers. The sage Bhrigu cursed him to be transformed into a serpent (sarpa) as punishment for his arrogance. The curse forced Nahuṣa to live in the earth, and he was later rescued by the sage Agastya. This story serves as a cautionary tale about the dangers of hubris and the authority of sages to enforce cosmic order.

entry.answer: The text recounts the story of a Chandala (low-caste individual) who steals soma (a sacred ritual drink) and other Brahmin property. This reflects the ancient Indian cultural emphasis on the sanctity of Brahminical resources and the severe karmic repercussions of violating social and religious hierarchies.
